title: 115_s1699
content: The Act titled "United States-Cuba Trade Act of 2017" removes provisions restricting trade and other relations with Cuba. The Act "United States-Cuba Trade Act of 2017" repeals authority for embargo and sugar quota under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and limits the President's authority under the Trading With the Enemy Act with respect to Cuba. The "United States-Cuba Trade Act of 2017" repeals regulations and prohibitions on exports to Cuba, allowing the President to impose new export controls with respect to Cuba. The "United States-Cuba Trade Act of 2017" repeals the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and allows the President to impose new export controls on Cuba under certain conditions. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 is repealed, along with related amendments in other acts. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996, along with related amendments, is repealed. This includes the removal of certain restrictions on assistance to former Soviet countries. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing restrictions on assistance to former Soviet countries and Cuba. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing restrictions on assistance to former Soviet countries and Cuba. Subsection (b) is struck, subsection (a) is modified by removing references to exports to Cuba, and section 909 (22 U.S.C. 7208) is repealed. Repeal of various sections including section 909 and section 910 of the Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000. Repeal of prohibition on transactions or payments with respect to certain United States intellectual property and sugar quota prohibition under the Food Security Act of 1985. SEC. 3 authorizes common carriers to install, maintain, and repair telecommunications equipment in Cuba and provide services between the US and Cuba, including upgrades. SEC. 4 pertains to travel. SEC. 4 allows for unrestricted travel to and from Cuba for US citizens and residents, including transactions related to such travel. This includes normal banking transactions involving foreign currency. The President should advance negotiations with Cuba to settle US nationals' property claims and protect human rights. Definitions of "national of the United States" and "property" are based on the International Claims Settlement Act of 1949. Additionally, there is an extension of nondiscriminatory trade treatment. The Congress supports promoting democratic change and economic reform in Cuba by normalizing trade relations. Upon enactment of the Act, the US will no longer need to use article XXI of the GATT 1994 with respect to Cuba. The President retains authority to invoke article XXI of the GATT 1994 in the future. The Uruguay Round Agreements Act extends nondiscriminatory treatment to Cuban products by amending the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States and repealing section 401 of the Tariff Classification Act of 1962. Additionally, the application of title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 to Cuba is terminated. Nondiscriminatory treatment (normal trade relations) will now apply to Cuban products, and the application of title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 to Cuba will cease. The effective date for these changes will be the 15th day after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the President is required to submit a report to Congress on trade relations between the United States and Cuba within 18 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 7 prohibits limiting remittances to Cuba by individuals under U.S. jurisdiction, except for certain offenses. SEC. 8 mandates reporting to Congress before denying foreign tax credit for specific foreign countries. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 changes the process for determining if a foreign country qualifies for certain tax credits. The amendment applies to determinations made after the enactment of the Act and does not affect countries already denied foreign tax credit. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 affects the process for determining if a foreign country qualifies for tax credits. It applies to countries determined to be described in paragraph (2)(A) of the subsection before the enactment of the Act. SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment, except as provided in sections 6 and 8.
